When the IG says serves SHALL support _include=ExplanationOfBenefit:*, is the intention that this query

  1. would return all five resource types for which explicit _includes are defined, meaning it's the same as:
_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:patient&
_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:provider&
_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:care-team&
_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:coverage&
_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:insurer
  1. would return all resources linked to from the EoB (not just for CARIN search params, but all core FHIR search params)?

I believe this would mean any search parameter of type=reference that the server supports. For the purpose of this IG, that means the ones listed as supported in the IG (option 1), but would not preclude servers from supporting more.
Technically if it was "any search parameters of type=reference that the server supports" , this would be just patient -- the other includes aren't targeting search parameters that CARIN requires

There is certainly some work that can be done in better defining a search parameter requirements and expectations. I do believe the intent was to, at a minimum, provide the full set of otherwise defined includes for ExplanationOfBenefit.

@Josh Mandel Would you mind adding a Jira ticket for what you would like to see in behavior and how that definition behavior might be defined in the IG? Always looking for ways to improve this and other IGs.

Isn't the behavior defined in the base specs? 'the wild card "*" for the search parameter name, indicating that any search parameter of type=reference be included' (http://hl7.org/fhir/search.html#revinclude)
Yes, but the CARIN IG seems to mean something slightly different.

I am not familiar with the history of this area on the IG, but looking at it, it seems the intent was to act as a sort of specialized $everything. It does not make much sense for patient to be a search parameter because all searches in this IG are performed by the patient and will only have access to their data.
I have added a ticket. https://jira.hl7.org/browse/FHIR-32982
Any further comment on how this issue should be addressed would be greatly appreciated, particularly from @Josh Mandel and @Michele Mottini

We had a long discussion about this during the development of the IG. Adding others who may be able to add some more color and history to this discussion. @Amol Vyas @Pat Taylor @Mark Roberts @Igor Sirkovich

The business intent of the IG is to, once a patient's EOB has been presented, to optionally allow searches on the reference resources, Coverage, Patient, Practitioner, and Organization. Reference FHIR-26693 and FHIR-27921. @Ryan Howells @Josh Mandel @Michele Mottini @Amol Vyas @Corey Spears @Mark Roberts @Igor Sirkovich

@Pat Taylor , Is the intent to be able to retrieve the referenced resources after the EoB has been retrieved or to be able to retrieve the EoB and all referenced resources together? The former is handled through GET operations using the references in the EoB, the latter is handled through an _include. As defined right now, the _include is problematic because they are supposed to only be resources that are also search parameters. The resources can be retrieved separately without the use of _include.

@Corey Spears The intent is to allow the app to either retrieve the referenced resources after the EOB has been retrieved or to retrieve the EOB and all reference resources together. However, the reference resources cannot be retrieved without first retrieving the EOB; i.e., they are always retrieved within the context of the EOB
I'm worried that defining the behavior of * in an IG specific way will prevent servers from supporting this IG alongside other IGs. (Imagine if each IG imposed its own rules for how * worked...)

I don't perceive an actual difference here - I think people are talking past each other.

The IG requires support for 5 particular _includes, as per the capability statement. 4 of them are standard search params (I think insurer isn't? maybe an oversight there?) It does not require the ability to search by these params, but it's not forbidden. You could trigger any of these includes individually.

The IG also requires _include:*. As per the standard, this will trigger every _include that the server supports, which will definitely be at least those 5 and potentially more.

From http://build.fhir.org/search

Both _include and _revinclude use the wild card "*" for the search parameter name, indicating that any search parameter of type=reference be included.

--> This is different from the CARIN IG guidance.

A Server SHALL be capable of supporting the following _includes:
ExplanationOfBenefit:patient - GET [base]/ExplanationOfBenefit?[parameter=value]&_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:patient
ExplanationOfBenefit:provider - GET [base]/ExplanationOfBenefit?[parameter=value]&_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:provider
ExplanationOfBenefit:care-team - GET [base]/ExplanationOfBenefit?[parameter=value]&_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:care-team
ExplanationOfBenefit:coverage - GET [base]/ExplanationOfBenefit?[parameter=value]&_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:coverage
ExplanationOfBenefit:insurer - GET [base]/ExplanationOfBenefit?[parameter=value]&_include=ExplanationOfBenefit:insurer

... which defines _include requirements without regard to search parameters. I think there's also a question of what the CARIN IG expects should happen with _incldue=* -- is the expectation that clients will get these five things, or at least these five things? The latter would help, and is worth spelling out if that's the intention.

How is that without regard for search parameters? Those names are search parameters.

Why does the IG need to spell out its intention for _include=*? It's a feature in the standard. They can require it by saying "we require it".
I mean -- distinct from support for search params.

It's a feature in the standard. They can require it by saying "we require it".

This should be right, but I'm worried implementers are very likely to "over-read" (and build brittle implementations) if we don't state our expectations.

I just don't see a difference in intent - it's only a question of how do you declare that you want _include for some search params but you don't require search by them? There's already a different field in the capability statement where the includes go.

To be clear, I don't think there's a huge issue here. Just want emphasize that implementers supporting the CARIN BB IG can/should use their existing _include=* behavior and shouldn't limit it to "just the CARIN five fields".
